title: Are mridangam and pakhwaj the same instruments, just known by different names in different regions? If not, how do they differ? - Quora

response.answer_text: Superficially, the two instruments are similar. Mridangam is known as the south-Indian Pakhawaj, and Pakhawaj is known as the north-Indian Mridangam (since we can't tell which came first). However there are some major differences in the construction, technique of playing and tones of the instruments.Mridangam has a shell usually made of a jackfruit tree. The two ends are fastened tightly to the body with a leather strap that passes through it 16 times! This is one feature of Mridangam that sets it apart from the other percussion instruments. The pressure is the determining aspect for producing the right rhythm. The instrumentalist usually places it on his foot and ankle as shown in the image below :   Pakhawaj, has a thicker body than Mridangam and it's two ends have wider circumferences. It also has a slightly heavier timbre. While Mridangam has "thekas" i.e continuous beats of certain notes maintained throughout a composition, pakhawaj are often silent and without any beat. This feature sets it apart from Tabla, which was derived from Pakhawaj and has majorly replaced it. Pakhawaj is a standard accompaniment instrument in Dhrupad and Dhammar music. It is placed in front of the instrumentalist who sits cross-legged, as shown below :
Pakhawaj has a unique feature and it is class apart. On the bass side we apply atta or dough. it gives a bold yet melodious sound. In Mridang on both side you have Sahi.
